star.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: a large ball of burning gas in space that can be seen at night as a point of light in the sky
star.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: I lay on my back and looked up at the stars.
The sky was filled with stars.
The stars were all out  (=they were shining).
The stars were twinkling overhead  (=shining and quickly changing from bright to faint).
sitting around a campfire under the stars
star.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: a famous and successful actor, musician, or sports player
star.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: By the age of 20, she was already a big star (=a very famous and successful performer).
He is a rising star (=someone who is becoming famous and successful) in the music world.
She’s a good actress but she lacks star quality (=a special quality that could make someone a star).
star.translation[0].definitions[2].signp: main person in a film/play etc
star.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: the person who has the main part, or one of them, in a film, play, show etc
star.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: Ray Grimes, the star of the television series ‘Brother John’
star.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: the person who gives the best performance in a film, play, show etc
star.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: Laporte, as Ebenezer Scrooge, is undoubtedly the star of the show.
Shamu, the killer whale, is the show’s star attraction (=best and most popular person or thing).
star.translation[0].definitions[4].defin: the best or most successful person in a group of players, workers, students etc
star.translation[0].definitions[4].examp: the star columnist of ‘The Sunday Times’
star.translation[0].definitions[5].defin: a shape with four or more points, which represents the way a star looks in the sky
star.translation[0].definitions[6].defin: a mark in the shape of a star, used to draw attention to something written
star.translation[0].definitions[6].examp: I put a star next to the items that we still need to buy.
star.translation[0].definitions[7].defin: a piece of cloth or metal in the shape of a star, worn to show someone’s rank or position – used especially on military uniforms
star.translation[0].definitions[8].defin: a mark used in a system for judging the quality of hotels and restaurants
star.translation[0].note_box[0].heading: – Meaning 1: a large ball of burning gas in space that can be seen at night as a point of light in the sky
star.translation[0].note_box[0].sections: I looked up and saw hundreds of stars shining in the sky.
Stars began to twinkle in the darkening night sky.
We arrived home just as the stars were coming out.
There was a full moon, and the stars were out.
I had spent a lot of time looking up at the stars as a kid.
In the desert, they slept out under the stars.
the brightest star in the night sky
The star is faint but visible.
He stared up towards the distant stars.
He fixed his telescope on a tiny little cluster of stars in the constellation of Taurus.
star.translation[0].note_box[1].heading: – Meaning 2: a famous and successful actor, musician, or sports player
star.translation[0].note_box[1].sections: He has worked with some of the world’s biggest stars.
He looked like a movie star.
Most TV stars do quite a lot of charity work.
She was known as a soap star before she took up singing.
Sam was a football star in college.
His performance in 'The Titanic' made him an international star.
She is very much the rising star of Black American fiction.
The production team say they have been careful to look after all their child stars.
Winners get star treatment from the media.
He denied that the movie was just a star vehicle for Tom Hanks.
a star of stage and screen
Now this much-loved star of stage and screen has been made a Dame.
star.translation[0].note_box[2].sections: in the sky
star
a large ball of burning gas in space, which can be seen at night as a point of light in the sky
The dark night sky was clear and full of stars.
planet
one of the large objects that goes around the Sun, for example the Earth, Saturn, Mercury, or Mars
The planet Uranus was discovered in 1781.
sun
the star that gives us light and heat, around which the planets move. There are also many millions of other suns in the universe
The sun came out from behind a cloud.
a dying sun
moon
the round object that moves around the Earth every 28 days, or a similar object that goes around another planet
The moon rose in the night sky.
Titan is one of the moons of Saturn.
asteroid
a mass of rock that moves around the sun. Most asteroids are found between Jupiter and Mars
the asteroid belt
pulsar
a type of star that is far away in space and produces radiation and radio waves
quasar
an object like a star that is far away in space and shines extremely brightly
supernova
a very large exploding star
constellation
a group of stars that forms a particular pattern and has a name
The constellation of Orion is one of the most easily recognizable patterns of stars in the night sky.
galaxy
one of the large groups of stars that make up the universe
Astronomers have detected a galaxy 11 billion light years away.
the universe
all space, including all the stars and planets
How many planets in the universe have life?
star.translation[0].note_box[3].sections: a famous person
star
a famous and successful actor, musician, or sportsperson
She dreamed of becoming a movie star.
a talent show to find the stars of the future
celebrity
someone who often appears in newspapers, on television etc and is well-known to the public. Celebrities are often famous for being famous, not because they have any great talent
The magazine is full of gossip about celebrities.
name
a famous person whose name is known by many people – used especially in the following expressions
All the big names in football were at the awards dinner.
Giorgio Armani is one of the most famous names in fashion.
He is yet to become a household name (=someone who everyone has heard of).
personality
an entertainer or sports player who is famous and often appears in the newspapers, on television etc – used especially in the following phrases
Many advertisers use TV personalities to promote their products.
He was chosen as sports personality of the year.
a very famous person
superstar
an extremely famous performer, especially a musician or film actor
The film made Tom Cruise an international superstar.
legend
someone who is famous and admired for being extremely good at doing something – used especially about people who are at the end of a long career or who have died
blues legend John Lee Hooker
Jane Fonda is the daughter of film legend Henry Fonda.
someone who was one of the best players or performers that there have ever been
He was one of the all-time soccer greats.
star.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: if someone stars in a film, television show etc, they are one of the main characters in it
star.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: ‘The Freshman’ was Brando’s first starring role (=the most important part in a film) in ten years.
Eastwood starred in ‘The Good, the Bad, and the Ugly’.
DeVito stars opposite Dreyfuss in the movie.
Hugh Grant stars as the romantic hero.
star.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: if a film, television show, or play stars someone, that person is one of the main characters in it
star.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: The movie starred Orson Welles as Harry Lime.
star.translation[1].definitions[2].defin: to put an asterisk (=a star-shaped mark) next to something written
star.translation[1].definitions[2].note_: Star is usually passive in this meaning
star.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: in the GROWTH/SHARE MATRIX, a company or product with quite a large share of a market that is growing quickly
